title: Nine celebrities who have battled breast cancer
text:
Sheryl Crow was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2006. Nine celebrities who have battled breast cancer 
Sheryl Crow was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2006. 
About one in eight women will have breast cancer in their lifetime. 
In honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month, here are nine celebrities who have battled breast cancer. 
Be sure to pick up a copy of LNP’s Pink edition on Sunday. Almost the entire newspaper will be pink in honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and much of its content will focus on breast cancer issues. 
1. Tig Notaro 
Comedian Tig Notaro announced – and joked about – her breast cancer diagnosis during a 2012 set at Los Angeles’ Largo. A Netflix documentary called “Tig” documents her life after that performance and her struggle to get pregnant with her partner. Notaro had a double mastectomy with no reconstructive surgery and bared her scars during an HBO comedy special, in which she performed part of her set topless. 
2. Christina Applegate 
Christina Applegate was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2008. The “Married with Children” and “Anchorman” actress underwent a double mastectomy. She started the foundation “Right Action for Women “which helps women get cancer screenings who wouldn’t be able to otherwise due to lack of health coverage. 
3. Kathy Bates 
The actress revealed her battle with breast cancer on Twitter in September 2012. “Hey all, sort for the long silence. I was diagnosed with breast cancer 2 months ago & am recovering from a double mastectomy,” Bates wrote. “I don't miss my breasts as much as I miss Harry's Law. ;-) Thanks for all the sweet tweets. Y’all kept me going." 
4. Julie Harris 
The award-winning stage and screen actress was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 55. She spoke at Lebanon Valley College in December of 1993 to talk about her battle. Harris died from congestive heart failure in 2013 at 87. 
5. Sheryl Crow 
The nine-time Grammy award winner underwent a lumpectomy in 2006 after being diagnosed with breast cancer. She appeared on Larry King Live in 2006 and said that she suspected her cancer might have been linked to drinking out of a plastic water bottle that heated up in her car, a comment that has caused scientific debate. 
6. Melissa Etheridge 
Etheridge was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2004. At the 2005 Grammy Awards, she performed Janis Joplin’s “A Piece of My Heart” with Joss Stone while bald during her chemotherapy treatment. “I didn't think, oh, I'm going to be brave and go do it,” Etheridge told NBC . “I thought, well, am I going to be well enough? Okay, I think I'll have enough energy. Yeah, I can do that, right. Maybe that's courageous. I don't know. But it was just it's what I love to do.” 
7. Robin Roberts 
The “Good Morning America” anchor was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2007, which was followed by surgery, chemotherapy and radiation treatment. Roberts was honored with the Arthur Ashe Courage Award at the 2013 ESPYs. 
8. Amy Robach 
Roberts’ convinced her “Good Morning America” co-anchor Amy Robach to receive a mammogram on-air, which lead to Robach’s diagnosis. Robach spoke at 2015’s Pink: A Women’s Event, produced by LNP. Robach recounts her breast cancer experience in her new book, “Better.” 
9. Giuliana Rancic 
The “Fashion Police” host and former “E! News” anchor announced her breast cancer diagnosis on NBC’s “Today” show. Rancic underwent a lumpectomy and radiation. She appeared in Lancaster with her husband Bill at 2013’s Pink: A Women’s Event. Tags
